caption: Figure 1: In a 4-phase game hand abstraction task, the current goal is to classify hands A and B.
description: The figure shows a four-phase game tree for a hand abstraction task.  The top node represents the initial state. Each subsequent level represents a phase in the game. The branches from each node represent possible actions or outcomes. Hands A and B are shown in the third phase, highlighted to illustrate that the goal of the task at this point is to classify these two hands based on some criteria.

caption: Figure 4: Full abstraction setting experiment, trained for 5.5 × 10<sup>10</sup> iterations.
description: This figure displays the results of an experiment comparing the performance of different hand abstraction methods in a Texas Hold'em game. The experiment uses a full abstraction setting, meaning that all players use the same abstraction. The x-axis represents the number of training iterations, and the y-axis shows the exploitability (in millibig blinds per game). The figure shows that KRWI (2-RWI) performs better than KROI (2-ROI) and POI (0-ROI), and the KrwEmd method is able to further reduce exploitability depending on hyperparameter settings.

caption: Figure 5: Performance comparison of KrwEmd versus other imperfect recall signal abstraction algorithms considering only future information, trained for 3.7 × 10<sup>10</sup> iterations.
description: The figure compares KrwEmd's performance against other imperfect recall signal abstraction algorithms (Ehs and PaEmd) in a setting where only future information is considered.  It shows the exploitability (a measure of how well a strategy performs against optimal play) over the course of 3.7 x 10^10 training iterations. Different hyperparameter settings for KrwEmd are tested (16-4-1, 7-5-3, 1-1-1, and 3-5-7) showcasing its performance under various configurations. The plot helps evaluate KrwEmd's efficiency in comparison to existing algorithms in this specific scenario.
section: 5 K-Recall Winrate Abstraction with Earth Mover's Distance

caption: Figure 4: Full abstraction setting experiment, trained for 5.5 × 10<sup>10</sup> iterations.
description: This figure displays the results of an experiment evaluating the performance of different hand abstraction methods in a Texas Hold'em game setting.  The x-axis represents the number of training iterations, and the y-axis shows the exploitability (in milli big blinds per game).  The experiment uses a "full abstraction" setting where both players use the same abstraction method. Two sets of experiments are shown: one with symmetric abstraction (where both players use the same abstraction) and one with asymmetric abstraction (where one player uses a specific abstraction while the other uses full information). The various lines represent different hand abstraction methods including lossless isomorphism (LI), potential winrate isomorphism (PWI), K-recall winrate isomorphism (KRWI), and KrwEmd with different hyperparameter sets.
